Title: Zach Blas
BodyText: Zach Blas (West Virginia, USA) is an artist, filmmaker, and writer whose practice spans moving image, computation, theory, performance, and science fiction. Blas engages the materiality of digital technologies while also drawing out the philosophies and imaginaries lurking in artificial intelligence. The work on the left is is an immersive moving image installation that explores the religious unconscious of artificial intelligence emotion recognition. It features 10 channels of video and a 5.1 surround-sound design, incorporating machine-learning generated material related to religious weeping. Two towering steel sculptures hold screens secured between spikes that display computer graphics animations of crying eyes, evoking weeping religious statues, professional mourners, and medical test subjects.
Caption: Profundier, Zach Blas, 2022

Title: Hans Haacke
BodyText: Haacke is best known as a pioneer of institutional critique. Many of his works attempt to expose the connections between money, politics, and art. Haacke’s 1967 solo exhibition at the Hayden Gallery included works he called “systems,” produced with the “explicit intention of having their components physically communicate with each other, and the whole communicate physically with the environment.” Something I find particularly interesting about Haacke's work is that he works collaboratively with Javascript, databases, open source GIS tools and image editing programs.
Caption: Sphere in Oblique Air-Jet, Hans Haacke, 1967

Title: Martina Lussi
BodyText: Pictured to the left is an audio project with a continuous, almost architectural visualiser, built for Talk With Urban Landscapes (TWUL). This immersive project combines audio and visual elements to prompt the viewer to disconnect from the construct of time. It mirrors the sounds of what we can decifer as a landscape to enforce a meditative ryhthm and lull the listener.
Caption: Twul, Martina Lussi

Title: Iris
BodyText: This is an interactive installation by Haybe Studio that utilises a large monochrome LCD canvas to track viewer's body movement. It uses the passage of ambient light, not emission of light itself. The canvas is hooked up to a Kinect so users can see their movements reflected in real time. I love how something so simple as bodily movement is transformed here into digital artwork and scenery.
Caption: Iris, Haybe Studio, 2012

Title: Sebastian Schmieg
BodyText: "When it all started" is a text about art and the NFT landscape, consisting of 16 short fragments. Each of these fragments is also an NFT: a generative, animated website made up of the letters of the text fragment. I was really intrifued by this artwork by the in which it employs various NFTs into a highly ineractive design. This led me to explore Schmieg's other work and practises. Particularly, Schmieg focuses on labor, algorithmic management, and artificial intelligence. He works in a wide range of media including video, website, installation, artist book, custom software, lecture performance, and delivery service. The majority of his work is a direct commentary on the algorithmic circulation of images, texts, and bodies.
Caption: When it All Started, Sebastian Schmieg, 2022

Title: Grid Spreading
BodyText: The work pictured here is by a student named Naoki Tsutae that I discovered on a Processing library. The student has a wide array of interactive sketches on display. I liked this sketch in particular due to its high level of intricacy and atttention to detail. The dynamic algorithm is almost hypnotising. The smoothness of the interface encourages the viewer to play and interact whilst also prompting a curiosity to understand it's inner workings.
Caption: Grid Spreading, Naoki Tsutae

Title: Random Quark
BodyText: This is an interactive installation that uses image generation models in real time to transform part of the camera image into something, or someone, else. The themes of the transformation can be customised and they change every few seconds so that participants get a chance to play with many alter-egos. Random Quark says to achieve real-time rending they "built a custom pipeline that uses multiple RTX4090 GPU cards in parallel that receive frames from the client and respond with frames rendered by Stable Diffusion."
Caption: AI Transformations, Random Quark

Title: Pen Plotter
BodyText: This is generative drawing bot called Makeblock XY Plotter. The picture on the left is a growth pattern. The servo motor allows moving the pen to a specific vertical position, but we can generally think of this as a binary: up (not drawing) or down (drawing).
Caption: Pen Plotter, AxiDraw

Title: Drawbot
BodyText: This is a drawing generated by a bot. The instruction manual below guides you to "Build a drawing robot using two servo motors operated by any audio player." Whilst I haven't built this myself, I thought it was really cool and worth saving to attempt to build in the future.
Caption: TRS Drawbot, Make: Magazine

Title: Eno Henze
BodyText: Eno Henze is an artist, scenographer and designer based in Germany. Specialising in installation and stage design, his works examine how machines transform aesthetic reasoning and notions of the human. I was drawn to Henze when I disovered a gallery of his creative coding artwork (see left) that use algorithms to develop extraordinary shape and form. The works are so intricate that it evidently blurs the line between reality and digitality.
Caption: Creative Coding, Eno Henze
